What is the Cost for IVF?
A complete IVF cycle at our clinic costs about Rs 3,00,000 - and this is all-inclusive for all medical procedures. Medicines would cost about Rs  145000 more.

    Ovarian stimulation monitoring

    Anesthesia for egg retrieval

    Egg retrieval procedure

There is NO extra cost for doing ICSI or a blastocyst transfer !

Excluded services - not included in our IVF costs:

    Pre-IVF screening tests

    Embryo or sperm freezing or storage - these are optional services

The cost for freezing and storing embryos is Rs 70000 per year

The cost for thawing and transferring them is Rs 70000

We do NOT charge for followup consultations; or for reviewing test results.

data.response: Treatment for pus cells in semen is not necessary unless there is an actual infection present. Often, the presence of a few pus cells on a semen analysis report could be misinterpreted as an infection when they are actually immature sperm precursors. It's important to consult with a specialist who can accurately interpret the results before starting any treatment.

source.context: Pus cells in the semen - and how to make sense of the report The bottom line is if your semen report does show a few pus cells, please don't panic ! Please repeat it again, and ask the lab to do the special stains needed to check if these are actually WBCs. Otherwise, your wife will keep on getting older and losing her fertility, while you waste time because of a poor quality laboratory, or a poorly informed gynecologist .

Pus cells in the semen - and how to make sense of the report One of the common findings in a semen analysis report is the presence of a few pus cells per high power field ( pus cells/ hpf). The technical word for this is called pyospermia or leucocytospermia. Pus cells are WBCs - white blood cells, and less than 5 pus cells / hpf is considered to be normal, but this finding is often highlighted in red as being abnormal, and this often causes both the doctor as well as the patient to worry.The WHO Manual states that less than 1 million WBC per ml is normal, but the majority of labs never bother to measure the actual concentration of the WBCs - the technician simply eyeballs the sample and estimate this in terms of rounds cells seen in each visual field when scanning the samples through the microscope. Patients are worried that these pus cells suggest they are suffering from an occult infection - perhaps a sexually transmitted disease ( STD) which they knew they had acquired in the past, and they are worried that they can transmit this to their wife.They are also worried that this hidden infection can kill their sperm, or reduce their ability to fertilise the eggs.Doctors are also happy to "treat" this abnormality by putting the man on antibiotics, because these are so easy to prescribe, and because this seems to be a logical thing to do. They hope these antibiotics will kill the bugs causing the infection, and this will boost the man's fertility. The reason this is flawed logic is because the "pus cells" seen on a semen analysis report when checked through the microscope are simply round cells, which are misinterpreted as being pus cells .When examining the semen under the microscope, it's very easy to identify sperm because they have a tail and are moving rapidly. However, seminal fluid also contains many other cells, including the epithelial cells which line the male reproductive tract, as well as sperm precursor cells. Most laboratory technicians will report every round cell they see as a pus cell or a WBC , but most of these are actually immature sperm precursors, called spermatocytes or spermatogonia , which look exactly the same. However, most labs don't have the special stains needed to identify whether this round cell is a WBC or not , which is why they will report all the round cells as pus cells !The doctor then promptly prescribes antibiotics, but this is a complete waste, because there was no infection in the first place, and antibiotics will not cause the sperm precursor cells to go away !Patients end up wasting a lot of time and money on taking antibiotics . Some doctors will also send the semen sample to the microbiology lab to try to culture the microbe causing the purported infection.

data.response: Treatment for pus cells in semen is not necessary unless there is an actual infection present. Often, the presence of a few pus cells on a semen analysis report could be misinterpreted as an infection when they are actually immature sperm precursors. It's important to consult with a specialist who can accurately interpret the results before starting any treatment.

source.context:
What type of startups are you interested in?
I am interested in early-stage startups with paying customers and a pre-money valuation of about Rs 10-50  crores. [Read More](https://www.indianangel.in/i-would-like-entrepreneurs-to-suggest-names-of-startups-i/7145/)

Are we the right investors for you? Finally, our sweet spot is the angel stage. We like to come in early and work closely with entrepreneurs who are building their ventures. Our ticket size is anywhere between Rs 50 lacs to 150 lacs depending on the age, maturity of business model, and our comfort level with the entrepreneurs. At the same time, we also provide the entrepreneur with an unwavering support in their quest to grow their venture, and at times also participate in bridge and follow on rounds to show solidarity. Because we like to come in early and bet on yet unproven business models untested at scale, we prefer to have sizeable skin in the game for it to make it worth our while. While we do not like to negotiate with entrepreneurs on the valuation of their ventures and want them to propose the valuation they are comfortable with, we prefer pre-money valuations between Rs 5 cr to 15 cr above which it has to be either an extremely superior business model or very strong credibility of the entrepreneur for us to consider our participation. And until it is time for the startups to learn from professional venture capitalists, we will be happy to handhold them in all walks of life.We are always looking for exciting new startups to invest in, and bright entrepreneurs to learn from. If your startup fits our investment thesis as mentioned above, we would love to hear from you.

When I first started investing in startups, we would take ... When I first started investing in startups, we would take pride in saying Yes quickly, and No quickly as well. After 4 years, we are no longer willing to say yes quickly, and spend a  lot more time on due-diligence! We have  realised the hard way that being able to pick the right founders makes a big difference to the outcome of the startups we fund, and that it's hard to judge a founder's character without having multiple interactions over time with them ,

Most investors prefer funding new startups , in the hope ... Most investors prefer funding new startups , in the hope that they will be able to find the next unicorn . Startups which have been plodding along for many years find it very hard to attract investors , because they haven't been able to show exponential growth during their journey .  However, these are actually a better bet for angel investors , because they are proven to be antifragile ! The founders have learned a lot about their domain , and have a reputation to protect. They have existing customers , and can tap into their network to grow, once they are funded.  Also, the competition for investing in these start-ups is much less , which means the pre money valuation is also much more reasonable ! ,

The MVP (minimum viable product) myth A \u201cminimum viable product\u201d - MVP - is also a highly abstract concept in the mind of the entrepreneur.     After all, viability can only be judged by the user!      And let\u2019s admit it: what is minimally viable depends largely on your audience\u2019s tolerance for lack of quality.    From the book, Innovating: A Doer's Manifesto for Starting from a Hunch, Prototyping Problems, Scaling Up, and Learning to Be Productively Wrong by Luis Perez-Breva

With the last questions, you are not looking for design advice; test subjects aren\u2019t good at that.  Instead, you are probing for unmet needs.  So, if they say something\u2019s missing, your response should be, \u201cOkay, why would you want that? \u201d A question to avoid is \u201cWould you use this? \u201d As with interview and survey questions, the answer from someone eager to please will too often be \u201cyes. \u201d

MVP Testing.  Prototyping and prototype testing should proceed in iterative loops until a dominant design emerges.  Based on test feedback, designers should reject some prototypes and refine others, producing higher-fidelity versions.  Once they converge on a single, favored solution, it\u2019s time for minimum viable product testing. 

An MVP is a prototype\u2014a facsimile of the future product.  What distinguishes an MVP from other prototypes is how it is tested.  Rather than sitting across a table, getting verbal feedback from a reviewer, you put a prototype that seems like a real product in the hands of real customers in a real-world context.  The goal is to quickly but rigorously test assumptions about the demand for your solution\u2014and gain what Eric Ries calls \u201cvalidated learning\u201d\u2014with as little wasted effort as possible.  A good MVP should embody the lowest fidelity possible to get reliable feedback because lower fidelity implies less wasted effort.  Put another way, an MVP should provide no more \u201clooks like\u201d polish and \u201cworks like\u201d functionality than is strictly necessary to conduct a test.  Functionality comes in two flavors.  Front-end functionality encompasses everything directly experienced by customers; for Wings it was daters\u2019 profiles, daily matches, messaging, search, etc.  Back-end functionality is invisible to the customer but integral to serving them.  For Wings, this would include the life-stream connectors, the matching algorithm, the servers, etc. 

MVPs come in four basic types, depending on whether they constrain front-end functionality, back-end functionality, or both:

Constrained Front-End Functionality.  These MVPs omit peripheral product features and focus only on the solution\u2019s core front-end features.  If customers don\u2019t perceive the core features to be valuable, there\u2019s no point in building the rest. 

Constrained Back-End Functionality.  MVPs can rely on makeshift, temporary methods to perform functions that are not visible to the customer\u2014for example, having humans analyze digital data to suggest matches instead of relying on software algorithms.  Again, there\u2019s no point in investing in automation until demand is validated.

210  ACQUIRING THE TREASURE It\u2019s time to revisit the all-important subject of valuation. In my first financing, we had a pre-money valuation of $5 million for our startup, Brainstorm. Since my cofounder and I owned most of the company,  I thought that meant we were multimillionaires, at least on paper. As we saw in Startup Model #5: The Four Quadrants of Hiring this was a result of not understanding what went into a valuation. Here is another misconception of entrepreneurs who want to sell stock,

Securities Offered   Most of the investment would be of preferred shares, as opposed to common shares (yours).  The preferences of the preferred shares are usually in case of a liquidation event and special rights, as will be described later in the table.      Company Valuation   This is the main deal, together with the amount that constitutes the transaction (\u201cHow much for how much? \u201d).  Valuation defines how much what was built so far is worth.  There is no methodological way to define it, so most likely it will be negotiated based on your alternatives.  It is defined as pre-money valuation, which is the value of what was created so far, and together with the investment amount, that forms the post-money valuation\u2014the value of the company once the round is finalized.  There will be an immediate derivative of this valuation, which is PPS (Price Per Share) and number of shares in the company (prior to the round).    Mathematically, this is: pre-money valuation = PPS \u00d7 number of shares prior to the round.  And then the company issues new shares to the investors at the same PPS in a total amount of the investment amount.    One note: It is important to realize that while ISO/ESOP is critical to attract and retain employees, it is mostly used by the investor as a way to lower valuation.  ISO/ESOP allocation requires issuing more shares, a new share per option, essentially increasing the number of shares and therefore lowering the PPS.  So, a $10 million pre-money valuation with 10 percent ISO/ESOP is actually less than $9 million.  It is common practice that ISO/ESOP allocation comes from current shareholders and not new ones.  To have better negotiation leverage you will need another competitive offer.      Pre-emptive Rights; Right of First Refusal; Co-Sale   Pre-emptive rights\u2014The investor will have the right to participate in the next round to maintain its holding; so, for example, an investor with 10 percent of the company that participates in the next round can maintain its 10 percent position.  While it may seem fine that all they want is to increase their position, it may discourage the next investor.  Or, even worse, the next investor may ask for similar terms!    Right of first refusal\u2014The investor has the right to invest under the same terms as a new investor.

But modern cognitive behavioral therapists have discovered a much more immediate and accessible source of emotions: your current train of thought.

source.context:
Can you can ask to be deferred if you are not ready?
You may not be ready for revalidation and so what do you do?
From: https://www.rcgp.org.uk/

Become a Designated Body!
Some organisations are automatically designated, these are listed in the Schedule Part 1 of the responsible officer regulations. Other organisations, the types are listed in the Schedule Part 25, are designated bodies when they have a prescribed connection with at least one doctor usually through employment or one of a variety of contract arrangements.
Content from: https://www.england.nhs.uk/professional-standards/medical-revalidation/emp-bod-hr/emp-faqs/#five

My Medical Appraiser Disagrees!
There are five key sign-off statements that are normally agreed by your appraiser at the end of your appraisal. If your appraiser decides that one, or more, should be marked as 'disagree', this sends a message to you, your next appraiser and the responsible officer (RO) that something may not be ready for revalidation. This is not, in itself, a bad thing. It is an important part of ensuring that the appraisal supports you in preparing a portfolio of supporting information appropriate for a positive recommendation to revalidate. Ultimately, your RO makes the decision about your revalidation recommendation, not your appraiser.
Content from: Mythbusters@RCGP

*Key Insights:*
*Concern Addressed:*
- The video addresses a common worry doctors might have \u2013 what happens if their appraiser disagrees with one of the sign-off statements during the appraisal meeting.
*Five Key Sign-off Statements:*
- The video mentions five key sign-off statements that are typically agreed upon by the appraiser at the end of the appraisal. Disagreement with any of these statements is discussed in the video.
*Implications of Disagreement:*
- If the appraiser marks one or more statements as disagree, it signals to the doctor, the next appraiser, and the Responsible Officer (RO) that something may not be ready for revalidation. The video emphasizes that this isn't necessarily negative but a crucial part of the revalidation process.
*Decision-Making Authority:*
- The ultimate decision about revalidation recommendation lies with the Responsible Officer (RO) and not solely with the appraiser.
*Explanation Boxes:*
- The video explains that there are two comment boxes for the appraiser and one for the doctor to provide an explanation in case of disagreement. This allows for clarity and context.
*Common Scenarios for Disagreement:*
- It's noted that disagreement might occur in scenarios where a doctor made no progress with their previous Professional Development Plan (PDP), especially if it was their first-ever appraisal or if circumstances significantly changed.
*Special Cases for Disagreement:*
- The video highlights that even the fifth sign-off statement, indicating no concerns for patient safety, might need to be marked as disagree in specific cases, such as when a doctor is under investigation.
*Transparent Communication:*
- Transparent communication is stressed, with the doctor having the opportunity to enter comments in the provided box, fostering understanding and collaboration in the appraisal process.

source.context:
Whose Responsibility Is To Ensure That I Have My Annual Medical Appraisal In Time?
Thank you for watching this video.
If you like the content here, please don't forget to like, share and subscribe!
GMC statutory guidance states that, to maintain your licence to practise, you must ensure that you have an annual medical appraisal and demonstrate your continued competence across your whole scope
of practice. Your responsible officer (RO) has a duty to ensure that there is a suitable, quality assured, appraisal process for you to participate in. The GMC requires you to engage with your annual appraisal process on an ongoing basis. Some doctors do not have an RO, or a Suitable Person, and still organise their own annual appraisal that meets the GMC criteria for a medical appraisal for revalidation.
If you work in a designated body with an organisational appraisal policy, it is your responsibility to understand what that means for you and how you should be accessing your annual appraisal. Your RO has a statutory responsibility for ensuring that the appraisal process is fit for purpose but you must play your part in engaging fully with the process.
We recommend that you are proactive in ensuring that you have an annual appraisal that is meaningful and meets your personal and professional development needs in the context in which you work. If your appraisal becomes disproportionately burdensome, we recommend that you speak to your appraiser and RO. They can support you and make recommendations.
If you think that you should be offered an appraisal and you are not, we recommend that you are proactive about seeking advice from your designated body and ensuring that you are included in the appraisal
process. Administrative errors do happen and you are best placed to highlight such omissions.

Do you work Friday and Saturday? At Medical Appraisals, we typically operate during regular working hours from Monday to Friday.  However, if you need a different arrangement for your appraisal meeting, feel free to let us know and we can accommodate you over the weekend too. [Watch Video](https://youtube.com/watch?v=qefgyMX1Dlk)

How much time should I spend preparing for my Medical appraisal?
Organising supporting information into your portfolio, and making the sign-offs and statements before appraisal discussion, should not take long. 
We recommend that your supporting information should be generated from your day-to-day work and added to your portfolio as you go along. Producing a CPD log can be difficult and time-consuming as a retrospective exercise. It is much easier to make regular entries into your learning diary throughout the year. There are now many tools and apps to help you to do this in a simple and timely way.

Key Insights:

The video addresses a common query about the amount of time one should spend preparing for their appraisal.
Efficient Organization of Supporting Information:
Organizing supporting information into the appraisal portfolio and completing sign-offs and statements before the appraisal discussion is emphasized.
Integration of Day-to-Day Work:
Supporting information is recommended to be generated from day-to-day work and added to the portfolio regularly, avoiding the need for a time-consuming retrospective exercise.
CPD Log Production:
Producing a Continuing Professional Development (CPD) log can be challenging and time-consuming as a retrospective exercise. Regular entries into a learning diary throughout the year are encouraged.
Use of Tools and Apps:
Various tools and apps are mentioned to simplify the process of maintaining a learning diary, making it simple and timely.
Time Allocation for Final Organization:
The final stage of organizing supporting information and completing the portfolio is recommended to take no more than half a day.
Historical Financial Provision Basis:
The recommendation is based on the historical financial provision for an annual appraisal, originally allocated for one day of activity \u2014 half for preparation and half for the discussion.
Discussion with Appraiser:
If the preparation is taking longer than four hours or feels disproportionate, individuals are advised to discuss this with their appraiser to explore ways to simplify the process.
Consideration for Complex Portfolio Careers:
Doctors with complex portfolio careers may reasonably take a little more time than suggested, but seeking advice is encouraged if it takes more than a day to organize content.

Three-Step Process for Appraisal:

Complete the MAC form or your portfolio as best as you can.

The appraisal process typically lasts about an hour and a half, but the duration can vary based on the information exchanged.
The meeting can be conducted over Skype, Zoom, or any other video technology preferred by the individual being appraised.

No Pass or Fail, Supportive Approach:
Emphasizes that the appraisal is not an examination or test; there's no pass or fail.
Professor Qazi is there to help and support through the process, not to be judgmental.

Flexibility and Individualized Approach:
Acknowledges that not every blank in the form needs to be filled and discusses those details during the appraisal meeting.
Recognizes the variability in the duration of the appraisal process based on the information and feedback exchanged.

Can you use any portfolio for your appraisal?
The format of the portfolio of supporting information is not prescribed by the GMC, so having an electronic portfolio is not a requirement for revalidation. 
Content from: Mythbusters@RCGP



Key Insights:

Introduction: Professor Rayan Kazi from Medical Appraisals UK presents a video addressing a common query regarding the use of a portfolio of choice for appraisal, especially targeted at doctors seeking self-appraisal.

Source of Content: The content of the video is sourced from Mythbusters at the Royal College of General Practitioners (rcgp), indicating reliance on reputable sources within the medical community.

Portfolio Format: The format of the portfolio of supporting information is not prescribed by the General Medical Council (GMC). An electronic portfolio is not mandatory for revalidation, offering flexibility in the choice of format.

Recommendations for Portfolio: It is recommended that the portfolio includes all core elements required by the GMC. The suggested format is professionally presented, typed for legibility, and capable of electronic transmission.

Confidentiality of Supporting Information: Certain supporting information, such as original complaint letters and handwritten complement cards, is recommended to be kept in paper form and shared privately with the appraiser to maintain confidentiality. These can then be referenced anonymously in the summary.

Medical Appraisal Guide Model Form: The Medical Appraisal Guide model form by NHS England is highlighted as a free interactive PDF available from the NHS England website. It serves as a template for all other toolkit providers, with its use not restricted to England alone.

National Platforms in Scotland and Wales: In Scotland and Wales, national appraisal and revalidation platforms (SOAR in Scotland and MARS in Wales) are mentioned, providing a standardized approach for all doctors.

Responsibility of Responsible Officers (ROs): Responsible officers may express a preference among available options, and doctors are encouraged to check with designated body requirements and variations. Special arrangements might be needed for accessibility issues related to a protected characteristic.

Moving to a New Area: When relocating to a new area in the UK, it is advised to check if a preferred local choice of the portfolio is being used.

Portfolio Accessibility: Doctors are reminded that the portfolio, containing all GMC-required supporting information, should be available to the responsible officer potentially at short notice.

Our aim is to provide a simple, cost effective, certified and robust appraisal service to our fellow doctors in line with the requirements of the NHS England and the GMC.

Can supporting information from work overseas be included in a medical appraisal?
This video explains if supporting information from work overseas can be included in the appraisal portfolio of doctors.

From: RCGP-Revalidation-Mythbusters-2016.pdf

Designated body At Medical Appraisals, we offer a medical appraisal service for doctors.   Our goal is to provide a smooth and efficient appraisal process tailored to your needs.  We can offer some very valuable advice as regards your designated body options at the time of the appraisal meeting.   Is there a specific aspect of our services you would like more information about?

Medical Appraisal Requirements For Overseas/ Non-UK Doctors
The GMC requirement is that your appraisal and revalidation portfolio should include supporting information about every part of your scope of practice that requires a UK licence. As the above makes clear, your RO has the discretion to consider supporting information from other settings in making their revalidation recommendation.
Even in UK practice, you may attend CPD events overseas. It is appropriate to check that the content of such an event is applicable to your scope of practice rather than assuming that it will be acceptable. We recommend that you discuss any proposal to include any such additional supporting information with your RO in advance of your revalidation recommendation date. It is likely that clinical work overseas will have a significant overlap with clinical work in the UK. It may well be appropriate to include supporting information relating to work overseas when it demonstrates the quality of your reflective practice.
If you are unsure, use your appraisal as an opportunity to reflect on what is appropriate and proportionate with your appraiser, and then agree it with your RO before your revalidation recommendation is due. Content from: Mythbusters@RCGP
 
*Key Insights:*
*Common Query Addressed:*
- The video addresses a common question among appraisees: whether they can include supporting information from non-UK sources in their appraisal.
*Source of Content:*
- The information in the video is derived from Mythbusters at the Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP), emphasizing the reliability of the content.
*Practice Settings Abroad:*
- Doctors practicing overseas, where a UK license is not required, have the discretion to include supporting information from these settings. It's at their judgment whether such information is relevant to their scope of practice.
*GMC Requirements:*
- The General Medical Council (GMC) requires that the appraisal and revalidation portfolio include supporting information for every aspect of the scope of practice requiring a UK license.
*Discretion in Considering Information:*
- The Responsible Officer (RO) has the discretion to consider supporting information from non-UK settings when making revalidation recommendations. However, it is crucial to ensure that the content is applicable to the scope of practice.
*Communication with RO:*
- Doctors are encouraged to discuss any proposal to include additional supporting information from non-UK settings with their Responsible Officer before the revalidation recommendation date.
*Overlap with UK Clinical Work:*
- Clinical work overseas may overlap significantly with work in the UK. In such cases, it might be appropriate to include supporting information related to overseas work, particularly if it demonstrates the quality of reflective practice.
*Reflective Practice:*
- The video suggests using the appraisal as an opportunity to reflect on what supporting information is appropriate and proportionate. Discussion with the appraiser and agreement with the Responsible Officer is recommended before the revalidation recommendation.

data.response: Yes, we are interested in agri-tech startups. They are one of the sectors that may emerge stronger post shake down.

source.context: do you fund IT Saas COmpany Yes, we fund IT SaaS companies that align with our investment philosophy.  If you believe your business fits this criteria, please reach out to Dhruv with a one-pager on your business.

Startups are going to go through a shake down, and ... Startups are going to go through a shake down, and many in the travel and hospitality space are going to die as their cash flow dries up. Some sectors, such as agri-tech, tele-health and logistics may emerge stronger once this blows over ! My worry is that everyone is going to 'pivot' and try to dabble in these areas. Short sighted opportunism will be funded by investors, who will try to make hay while the sun shines, even though these startups don't have any right to win in these areas!  ,

Young startup founders are very enthusiastic, and when they get ... Young startup founders are very enthusiastic, and when they get introduced to business people in different domains, they want to apply their new technology for solving existing problems in this field. Most companies are happy to allow them to do pilots, because running a proof of concept costs them nothing. The problem is that these startups end up chasing too many different channels, most of which turn out to be dead ends. They finally end up running out of cash. You need to maintain focus and not get distracted, by learning to say No to projects which are not part of your core competence.  ,

Why is an acquirer interested in buying your startup? Is it to get your awesome product? Is it the people? Or is it because of the underlying technology you\u2019ve built? Maybe it\u2019s the customers or the revenues they really want?

What type of startups are you interested in?
I am interested in early-stage startups with paying customers and a pre-money valuation of about Rs 10-50  crores. [Read More](https://www.indianangel.in/i-would-like-entrepreneurs-to-suggest-names-of-startups-i/7145/)

Do you have any success stories or testimonials from entrepreneurs you've invested in?
I don't have any specific success stories or testimonials to share at the moment. As mentioned earlier, it's still early days for my investments and the startup ecosystem in India. Yu can check out our portfolio and speak to the founders we have invested in at https://www.malpaniventures.com/portfolio

Putting Education before Profits EduTech startups such as Byju's and Toppr are leveraging technology in order to reach out to as many students as possible .Sadly they are doing this primarily in order to generate profits.We need to provide students with a better alternative !These EduTech entrepreneurs have combined domain expertise , money and technology to make tons of money .And this is now being fueled by investors who want to make even more - at the expense of students !How can an entrepreneur who has his heart in the right place , and is more interested in creating value for students rather than in making money , use the same 3 building blocks ?This social impact startup will have a huge competitive edge , because you will be able to combine financial capital with human capital and social capital !If you think you are the right person to drive this, please reach out to me .I would like to find someone who's been in this field for at least 10 years , and has created tangible impact, . You should have enough hands on experience to know exactly what works in India , and what does not, and be willing to grow sustainably, and patiently.If you want to scale up digitally, please reach out to me for funding.My email is mapani@malpaniventures.com

I have a soft corner for startups which offer blended ... I have a soft corner for startups which offer blended models, which utilize a combination of both real life resources as well as online assets. These are more complex to establish, which means that they are harder to replicate, which is a useful competitive moat. More  importantly, they offer  the customer the best of both worlds, and this is a valuable competitive edge! It is my belief that technology becomes commoditised very quickly, but startups which use technology-powered human resources have the right to win, because they are taking  advantage of India's demographic sweet spot! For example, and edu tech company which uses live tutors, along with AI powered algorithms to provide personalized adaptive learning, can be an unbeatable combination!  ,

source.context:
My Responsible Officer Forgot To Remind Me That My Annual Medical Appraisal Is Due!
GMC statutory guidance states that to maintain your licence to practise, you must ensure that you have an annual medical appraisal and demonstrate your continued competence across your whole scope of practice. Your responsible officer (RO) has a duty to ensure that there is a suitable, quality-assured, appraisal process for you to participate in. The GMC requires you to engage with your annual appraisal process on an ongoing basis. It is your responsibility to ensure that you have an appraisal.
Content from: Mythbusters@RCGP

*Key Insights:*
*Responsibility for Annual Appraisal:*
- The video addresses the question of whether it is the responsibility of individual doctors or their Responsible Officer (RO) to ensure timely annual appraisals.
*GMC Statutory Guidance:*
- The GMC statutory guidance emphasizes that doctors must ensure they undergo an annual medical appraisal and demonstrate continued competence across their entire scope of practice.
*RO's Duty:*
- The RO has a duty to ensure there is a suitable, quality-assured appraisal process available for doctors. However, the responsibility to engage with the annual appraisal process lies with the individual doctor.
*Ongoing Engagement:*
- Ongoing engagement with the annual appraisal process is highlighted as the doctor's responsibility, emphasizing the need for proactive participation.
*Organizing Appraisal Without RO:*
- In cases where doctors do not have an RO or a suitable person, they are encouraged to organize an annual appraisal that meets GMC criteria for revalidation.
*Designated Body's Appraisal Policy:*
- For those working in designated bodies with organizational appraisal policies, doctors are urged to understand the policies and know how to access their annual appraisal.
*Proactive Approach:*
- Doctors are advised to be proactive in ensuring they have a meaningful annual appraisal that aligns with their professional and developmental needs within their specific working context.
*Seeking Advice:*
- If a doctor believes they should be offered an appraisal and are not, they are encouraged to seek advice from their designated body and take proactive steps to be included in the appraisal process.
*Role in Highlighting Errors:*
- Doctors are regarded as best placed to highlight administrative errors in the appraisal process, emphasizing their active role in the process.

Do Only Medical Courses And Conferences Count As CPD For Doctors?
Continuing professional development (CPD) activities should be very broadly defined and include personal, opportunistic and experiential learning as well as activities targeted at identifying \u2018unknown unknowns\u2019.

Key insights:

Broad Definition of CPD: CPD activity for doctors should be broadly defined, encompassing personal, opportunistic, and experiential learning. It should also include activities targeted at identifying unknown unknowns.

Inclusive Learning Activities: Any learning activity where time is spent learning something and deciding how it can be applied in current or proposed work can be counted as CPD. This extends beyond traditional courses and conferences.

Documentation Focus: Doctors are advised to expend time and energy documenting a sample of their most relevant and important learning. The goal is to demonstrate a balanced range of learning across the curriculum relevant to their scope of practice over the five-year revalidation cycle.

Diverse Learning Sources: CPD is not limited to courses and conferences; it can include learning from cases, data, events, personal reading, online research, online modules, and professional conversations about clinical care. Everyday learning from work and experiences of others, especially in teams, is also valuable.

Demonstrating Impact: It is important to demonstrate how learning, especially within primary care teams, has led to significant changes and developments. Sharing learning with others outside the usual workplace is encouraged for external calibration of ideas and processes.

Reflective Practice: For any learning activity, doctors need to reflect on what they have learned and any changes made as a result. Documentation and sharing should focus on the most valuable learning experiences.

Avoiding Disproportionate Recording: Doctors are cautioned against doing too much and making the recording of their CPD disproportionate. Documentation should not detract from patient care, family, or leisure time.

process for scheduling a medical appraisal The first step is to complete your appraisal portfolio.  Please inform us here once done and Prof Kazi will schedule a video appraisal meeting with you!

All About CPD or CME Activities For Medical Appraisal Requirements
This short video explains everything you need to know about CPD or CME activities for a doctor's appraisal. Know the essentials of Continuous Professional Development (CPD) or Continuing Medical Education (CME) with this informative video created for a doctor's medical appraisal process in the UK. Explore the significance of CPD/CME activities in maintaining professional competence and staying abreast of advancements in the medical field. This succinct guide covers the intricacies of planning, documenting, and reflecting on CPD/CME, ensuring compliance with appraisal requirements. Whether you're a medical professional seeking clarity on these crucial activities or an observer curious about the ongoing learning process, this resource is your gateway to a comprehensive understanding of CPD/CME in the context of medical appraisals.

Are Certificates Of Attendance At CPD Events Important For A Medical Appraisal?
Certificates of attendance may prove attendance at an event, but they are not proof of learning or development. They say nothing about what has been learned, or any changes you have made as a result.
A reflective note, no matter how brief, is far more valuable evidence of reflective practice and continuing professional development than a certificate. A lot of valuable learning takes place in ways that do not
generate a certificate, such as personal reading and professional conversations with colleagues. We encourage you to think about how and what you have learnt, defining one CPD credit as one hour of learning activity as demonstrated by a reflective note on the lessons learned and any changes made as a result.
You should not waste time scanning certificates of attendance into your portfolio of supporting information, unless keeping formal proof of attendance on courses that are organisational requirements may be useful
to you, such as Basic Life Support and Safeguarding. Appraisers should not be asking to see certificates of attendance; they should be asking what your most important new learning has been over the past year and what difference it has made to your practice.
Many CPD facilitators now provide certificates that include a structured format or template for you to write appropriate reflective notes about learning and planned changes that will have an impact on your practice.
It is reasonable to scan these rather than rewriting the reflective note elsewhere. You can also choose not to complete the certificate at all if the reflective note is captured elsewhere in a learning log or electronic
toolkit. Your aim should be to avoid duplication of effort.

key insight : from the provided information on Medical Appraisals in the UK is that certificates of attendance at Continuing Professional Development (CPD) events are considered proof of attendance but not sufficient evidence of learning or development. The video emphasizes that merely attending an event does not convey what has been learned or the impact on one's practice. Instead, the focus is on the importance of reflective practice, encouraging appraisers to provide reflective notes as more valuable evidence of CPD.

The video suggests that a brief reflective note is far more valuable than a certificate, as it demonstrates the individual's understanding of what was learned and any changes made as a result. The emphasis is on capturing the essence of the learning experience and its application to professional development. The content discourages the unnecessary inclusion of certificates of attendance in the appraisal portfolio unless required by the organization for specific courses.

Appraisers are advised to ask about the most significant new learning over the past year and its impact on practice, shifting the focus from proof of attendance to the meaningful outcomes of the learning process. Many CPD facilitators now provide certificates with structured formats or templates for writing reflective notes, making it reasonable to include these in the portfolio.

My Medical Appraisal Is On My Birthday!
There are a variety of ways to allocate your appraisal month. Most designated bodies follow NHS England guidance and spread appraisals through the appraisal year based on having your appraisal in your birth month. Other designated bodies may have a different way of allocating your appraisal month. 
Content from: Mythbusters@RCGP



*Key Insights:*

*Common Query Addressed:*
The video addresses a common query among doctors: whether they can choose the month of their first-ever appraisal.

*Ways to Allocate Appraisal Month:*
Various methods exist for allocating the appraisal month, with designated bodies often following NHS England guidance. The video mentions the possibility of aligning appraisals with one's birth month.

*Different Designated Body Approaches:*
Designated bodies may have different approaches, such as having an "appraisal season" or adjusting the month based on periods of leave.

*Changes When Moving Designated Bodies:*
When transitioning from one designated body to another, the responsible officer at the new body may request a change in the appraisal month to align with local policies and processes.

*Importance of Checking Appraisal Due Date:*
Doctors are advised to check when their appraisal is due, especially during transitions between designated bodies.

*Flexibility in Appraisal Month:*
The video highlights situations where the appraisal may not occur in the birth month, showcasing the flexibility in the process.

*Adjustments by Responsible Officers:*
Responsible officers may request changes in the appraisal month to ensure alignment with local policies and facilitate a smooth transition.

I must get sign off statements from all parts of my scope of work every year!
The RCGP does not recommend that you seek sign-off statements that there are no concerns about your practice in all of your roles every year. Instead, you should reflect on how the safety of patients is being assured and the governance, clinical or otherwise, of the systems you are working in.

Medical Appraisal For Doctors In UK Without A Designated Body
The annual return process of the GMC refers to the requirement for GMC registered doctors without a designated body to provide certain information to the GMC on an annual basis about their medical appraisal.

During the annual return process, doctors are required to confirm their contact details, provide information about their medical practice, and declare any changes in their health, fitness to practice, or any significant events that may impact their registration. This process helps the GMC maintain accurate records of doctors and ensures that they meet the necessary standards to practice medicine.

By completing the annual return, doctors fulfill their professional obligation to stay in touch with the GMC and provide the necessary updates. It allows the GMC to monitor the status and fitness to practice of registered doctors, as well as communicate important information and updates to them.


key insights:

Mandatory Annual Return: The GMC mandates that all UK registered doctors, whether they have a designated body or not, must complete an annual return.

Process for Doctors Without Designated Body: Doctors without a designated body must complete the annual return online through GMC online. They should receive an annual email reminder.

Information Required: The annual return process involves providing personal and professional details, current employment status, any significant health issues, and changes in employment since the last return.

CPD Requirements: Doctors must confirm compliance with the GMC's requirements for Continuing Professional Development (CPD) by undergoing an annual appraisal and submitting the Rev 12.

Declaration of Criminal Convictions: Doctors are required to declare any criminal convictions or ongoing investigations, essential for assessing fitness to practice and ensuring patient safety.

Deadline and Consequences: The deadline for completing the annual return is typically in March or April. Failure to meet the deadline may lead to removal from the medical register, requiring a restoration process.

Common Questions Addressed: The video anticipates and addresses common questions doctors may have about the annual return process, such as how to complete it, whether there's a fee, and when to expect reminder emails.

GMC's Focus: The GMC's annual return process aims to maintain accurate records, monitor professional conduct and qualifications, and uphold high standards of medical practice to ensure patient safety.

Plus, two good-looking chefs, who\u2019ve become the talk of the town! \u201d \u2014 LBB Bangalore  \u201cOkay I am not exaggerating when I say that this place serves the best pizzas in the city.  I love the sourdough base and the very authentic taste of the cheese and toppings.  I absolutely dig their quattro formaggi with the perfect blend of 4 different variants of cheese - mozzarella, Parmesan, provolone and blue cheese.  After a friends insisting I tried the Diavolo which was topped with baby aubergines which tasted amazing.  The Anna and shrooms are two other favourites.  Their garlic cheese bread is freshly baked and is perfectly seasoned.  \u201d  \u201cCannot begin to state how good this place was.  Hands down the BEST pizza and garlic bread I\u2019ve had in a long long time.  It was so good that in a 2 day trip to Bangalore we ended up going there twice .  Amazing amazing foood! \u201d"

Plus, two good-looking chefs, who\u2019ve become the talk of the town! \u201d \u2014 LBB Bangalore  \u201cOkay I am not exaggerating when I say that this place serves the best pizzas in the city.  I love the sourdough base and the very authentic taste of the cheese and toppings.  I absolutely dig their quattro formaggi with the perfect blend of 4 different variants of cheese - mozzarella, Parmesan, provolone and blue cheese.  After a friends insisting I tried the Diavolo which was topped with baby aubergines which tasted amazing.  The Anna and shrooms are two other favourites.  Their garlic cheese bread is freshly baked and is perfectly seasoned.  \u201d  \u201cCannot begin to state how good this place was. Or	you	may	be	experiencing	more	pain,which	motivates	you	more	than	your	mate.  In	either	case,	you	will	certainlybenefit	from	any	improvement	your	efforts	bring.  The	hope	would	be	that	as	therelationship	improves,	your	partner,	too,	will	assume	a	more	active	role. It	is	not	absolutely	necessary	for	both	partners	to	work	simultaneously	on	therelationship.  I	counseled	several	people	whose	spouses	were	unable	or	unwillingto	try	marital	therapy,	and	these	individuals	were	able	to	induce	favorablechanges	in	their	partners	by	virtue	of	the	benefit	they	had	received	from	theirown	therapy.

The	improvements	thatcouples	show	in	counseling	are	accompanied	more	by	a	reduction	in	unpleasantencounters	than	by	an	increase	in	pleasant	events.  Happiness	seems	to	comemore	naturally	when	the	negative	experiences	and	negative	interpretations	arediminished. Just	as	cognitive	therapy	can	help	patients	with	clinical	anxiety	or	depressionunderstand	their	erroneous	thinking,	the	same	principles	can	counteract	themisunderstandings	and	biases	of	distressed	marriages,	such	as	those	described	inthis	chapter.

Drs.  Janis	Abrahms,	David	Burns,	FrankDattilio,	Stowe	Hausner,	Susan	Joseph,	Chris	Padesky,	and	Craig	Wiese	areother	cognitive	therapists	who	have	pioneered	clinical	treatment	approaches	inmarital	therapy. In	view	of	the	success	of	cognitive	therapy	as	used	by	psychotherapists	andmarriage	counselors,	the	time	is	ripe	to	share	our	insights	with	the	public.  Thisbook	should	be	useful	to	mates	of	every	kind\u2014housemates,	roommates,bedmates\u2014and	of	the	same,	as	well	as	the	opposite,	sex.

Nowhere	is	the	\u201ccry	for	help\u201d	a	therapist	hears	morepoignant	than	among	those	clients	who	see	their	once	happy	marriage	begin	todissolve.  Even	couples	married	thirty	to	forty	years	may	feel	driven	to	end	arelationship	that	they	now	regard	as	an	unending	series	of	mistakes	and	miseries. source.context:
Will The Medical Appraiser Decide About My GMC Revalidation Recommendation?
This video clears the commonly held misconception that appraisers decide the revalidation recommendation for doctors.

key insight:

Appraiser's Role: The primary role of the appraiser is to facilitate the doctor's reflection, provide support, stimulate development, and help present an appropriate portfolio of supporting information for the Responsible Officer (RO) to consider.
Facilitating Documentation: Appraisers play a crucial role in producing a comprehensive summary of the evidence supplied by the doctor, representing them to the RO. This involves ensuring that the documentation complies with the requirements for revalidation.
RO's Statutory Responsibility: The RO holds the statutory responsibility for making the revalidation recommendation to the General Medical Council (GMC). The RO's decision is based on factors such as the doctor's engagement in annual appraisal, the quality of the supporting information portfolio, and any outstanding concerns within the scope of work.
GMC Revalidation Decision: Ultimately, the GMC makes the revalidation decision, determining whether to continue the doctor's license to practice.
Appraiser as a Resource: While the appraiser does not make the revalidation decision, they are a valuable resource in helping doctors improve the quality of documentation, especially in areas such as the quality of reflection and the relevance of supporting information across the entire scope of work.
Importance of Engagement: The video highlights that insufficient engagement is often related to the quality of reflection and the relevance of supporting information across the entire scope of work.
Professional Development Planning: Appraisers can support doctors in planning their professional development in a way that enhances the quality of their professional work.

Who Is My Designated Body For Medical Appraisal?
According to The Medical Profession (Responsible Officers) Regulations 2010(link is external), designated bodies are: 
Organisations that provide healthcare
Organisations that set standards and policy for the delivery of healthcare
Some specialist organisations that employ or contract with doctors. 
Content from: https://www.rcpe.ac.uk/careers-training/how-do-i-confirm-my-prescribed-connection-designated-body-and-responsible-officer



key insights:

Designated Bodies Definition: Designated bodies are organizations that play a crucial role in healthcare. They can be healthcare providers, organizations setting healthcare standards and policies, or certain specialized organizations employing or contracting with doctors.

Responsible Officer (RO): The majority of designated bodies have a Responsible Officer (RO) in place. RO is an important figure in the revalidation process and is responsible for overseeing the appraisal and revalidation of doctors within the designated body.

Prescribed Connection: Each doctor can have only one prescribed connection to a designated body. In most cases, this prescribed connection is where the doctor performs the majority of their clinical work.

Identifying Designated Body and RO: Doctors can identify their designated body and RO by setting up a GMC (General Medical Council) online account. The GMC website provides a full list of designated bodies, and doctors can use an online tool under the revalidation section to confirm their designated body.

Employment and Prescribed Link: If a doctor is employed by an NHS organization but works for another organization through contracted sessions, their prescribed link will be to the NHS organization and its RO, regardless of the time spent outside.

Confirmation of Designated Body: Once the designated body is confirmed, the RO should assist the doctor in identifying a suitable appraiser for the revalidation process.

No Designated Body Connection: If a doctor doesn't have a connection to any organization classified as a designated body, they should inform the GMC about their circumstances using their online account.

Finding a Responsible Officer: In cases where a responsible officer cannot be found, it may be possible to identify a suitable person. The GMC website provides more information and guidance on this.

Designated body At Medical Appraisals, we offer a medical appraisal service for doctors.   Our goal is to provide a smooth and efficient appraisal process tailored to your needs.  We can offer some very valuable advice as regards your designated body options at the time of the appraisal meeting.   Is there a specific aspect of our services you would like more information about?

data.response: Designated bodies are typically organizations where doctors work, such as hospitals or GP practices. In most cases, doctors have a prescribed connection to a designated body based on where they perform the majority of their clinical work.

source.context:
All you need to know about a 'designated body'
The revalidation of doctors is a crucial aspect of medical regulation aimed at ensuring ongoing professional development, accountability, and quality assurance in healthcare delivery. Designated bodies play a pivotal role in facilitating the revalidation process, overseeing the appraisal and performance assessment of doctors, and upholding standards of excellence in medical practice. 

In the United Kingdom, according to the Responsible Officer Regulations, a designated body is typically an organization or institution that employs or contracts with doctors and is responsible for the following:

1. Appointing responsible officers: Designated bodies appoint responsible officers who oversee the appraisal and revalidation of doctors within their organization.

2. Supporting appraisal and revalidation: Designated bodies provide support and resources for doctors to undergo appraisal, which involves regular assessment of their performance and professional development. They also facilitate the revalidation process, which is the periodic evaluation of doctors' fitness to practice.

3. Ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements: Designated bodies ensure that doctors meet the necessary standards of competence, conduct, and professionalism required by regulatory authorities such as the General Medical Council (GMC) in the UK.

Designated bodies in the context of Responsible Officer Regulations are typically healthcare organizations, including hospitals, general practitioner (GP) practices, and other healthcare institutions where doctors work. These bodies play a crucial role in maintaining the quality and safety of medical care by overseeing the appraisal and revalidation of doctors and ensuring compliance with regulatory standards.

Help with direct submission to GMC If you have no designated body and are doing a direct submission to the GMC, we can complete the REV12 form for you.  Would you like my colleague Prof.  Rehan to get in touch with you to advise further?

Other organisations, the types are listed in the Schedule Part 25, are designated bodies when they have a prescribed connection with at least one doctor usually through employment or one of a variety of contract arrangements.

source.context:
All you need to know about a 'designated body'
The revalidation of doctors is a crucial aspect of medical regulation aimed at ensuring ongoing professional development, accountability, and quality assurance in healthcare delivery. Designated bodies play a pivotal role in facilitating the revalidation process, overseeing the appraisal and performance assessment of doctors, and upholding standards of excellence in medical practice. 

In the United Kingdom, according to the Responsible Officer Regulations, a designated body is typically an organization or institution that employs or contracts with doctors and is responsible for the following:

1. Appointing responsible officers: Designated bodies appoint responsible officers who oversee the appraisal and revalidation of doctors within their organization.

2. Supporting appraisal and revalidation: Designated bodies provide support and resources for doctors to undergo appraisal, which involves regular assessment of their performance and professional development. They also facilitate the revalidation process, which is the periodic evaluation of doctors' fitness to practice.

3. Ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements: Designated bodies ensure that doctors meet the necessary standards of competence, conduct, and professionalism required by regulatory authorities such as the General Medical Council (GMC) in the UK.

Designated bodies in the context of Responsible Officer Regulations are typically healthcare organizations, including hospitals, general practitioner (GP) practices, and other healthcare institutions where doctors work. These bodies play a crucial role in maintaining the quality and safety of medical care by overseeing the appraisal and revalidation of doctors and ensuring compliance with regulatory standards.

Who Is My Designated Body For Medical Appraisal?
According to The Medical Profession (Responsible Officers) Regulations 2010(link is external), designated bodies are: 
Organisations that provide healthcare
Organisations that set standards and policy for the delivery of healthcare
Some specialist organisations that employ or contract with doctors. 
Content from: https://www.rcpe.ac.uk/careers-training/how-do-i-confirm-my-prescribed-connection-designated-body-and-responsible-officer



key insights:

Designated Bodies Definition: Designated bodies are organizations that play a crucial role in healthcare. They can be healthcare providers, organizations setting healthcare standards and policies, or certain specialized organizations employing or contracting with doctors.

Responsible Officer (RO): The majority of designated bodies have a Responsible Officer (RO) in place. RO is an important figure in the revalidation process and is responsible for overseeing the appraisal and revalidation of doctors within the designated body.

Prescribed Connection: Each doctor can have only one prescribed connection to a designated body. In most cases, this prescribed connection is where the doctor performs the majority of their clinical work.

Identifying Designated Body and RO: Doctors can identify their designated body and RO by setting up a GMC (General Medical Council) online account. The GMC website provides a full list of designated bodies, and doctors can use an online tool under the revalidation section to confirm their designated body.

Employment and Prescribed Link: If a doctor is employed by an NHS organization but works for another organization through contracted sessions, their prescribed link will be to the NHS organization and its RO, regardless of the time spent outside.

Confirmation of Designated Body: Once the designated body is confirmed, the RO should assist the doctor in identifying a suitable appraiser for the revalidation process.

No Designated Body Connection: If a doctor doesn't have a connection to any organization classified as a designated body, they should inform the GMC about their circumstances using their online account.

Finding a Responsible Officer: In cases where a responsible officer cannot be found, it may be possible to identify a suitable person. The GMC website provides more information and guidance on this.

Help with direct submission to GMC If you have no designated body and are doing a direct submission to the GMC, we can complete the REV12 form for you.  Would you like my colleague Prof.  Rehan to get in touch with you to advise further?

Designated body At Medical Appraisals, we offer a medical appraisal service for doctors.   Our goal is to provide a smooth and efficient appraisal process tailored to your needs.  We can offer some very valuable advice as regards your designated body options at the time of the appraisal meeting.   Is there a specific aspect of our services you would like more information about?

More info on designated bodies? Designated bodies are organizations crucial in healthcare, overseeing appraisal and revalidation of doctors. They appoint responsible officers, support appraisal/revalidation, ensure regulatory compliance. In the UK, they include hospitals, GP practices. Designated bodies uphold standards of excellence in medical practice. [Watch Video]( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4yZlLW54Sy4)

Can you use any portfolio for your appraisal?

Content from: Mythbusters@RCGP



Key Insights:

Introduction: Professor Rayan Kazi from Medical Appraisals UK presents a video addressing a common query regarding the use of a portfolio of choice for appraisal, especially targeted at doctors seeking self-appraisal.

Source of Content: The content of the video is sourced from Mythbusters at the Royal College of General Practitioners (rcgp), indicating reliance on reputable sources within the medical community.

Portfolio Format: The format of the portfolio of supporting information is not prescribed by the General Medical Council (GMC). An electronic portfolio is not mandatory for revalidation, offering flexibility in the choice of format.

Recommendations for Portfolio: It is recommended that the portfolio includes all core elements required by the GMC. The suggested format is professionally presented, typed for legibility, and capable of electronic transmission.

Confidentiality of Supporting Information: Certain supporting information, such as original complaint letters and handwritten complement cards, is recommended to be kept in paper form and shared privately with the appraiser to maintain confidentiality. These can then be referenced anonymously in the summary.

Medical Appraisal Guide Model Form: The Medical Appraisal Guide model form by NHS England is highlighted as a free interactive PDF available from the NHS England website. It serves as a template for all other toolkit providers, with its use not restricted to England alone.

National Platforms in Scotland and Wales: In Scotland and Wales, national appraisal and revalidation platforms (SOAR in Scotland and MARS in Wales) are mentioned, providing a standardized approach for all doctors.

Responsibility of Responsible Officers (ROs): Responsible officers may express a preference among available options, and doctors are encouraged to check with designated body requirements and variations. Special arrangements might be needed for accessibility issues related to a protected characteristic.

Moving to a New Area: When relocating to a new area in the UK, it is advised to check if a preferred local choice of the portfolio is being used.

Portfolio Accessibility: Doctors are reminded that the portfolio, containing all GMC-required supporting information, should be available to the responsible officer potentially at short notice.

Whose Responsibility Is To Ensure That I Have My Annual Medical Appraisal In Time?
Thank you for watching this video.
If you like the content here, please don't forget to like, share and subscribe!
GMC statutory guidance states that, to maintain your licence to practise, you must ensure that you have an annual medical appraisal and demonstrate your continued competence across your whole scope
of practice. Your responsible officer (RO) has a duty to ensure that there is a suitable, quality assured, appraisal process for you to participate in. The GMC requires you to engage with your annual appraisal process on an ongoing basis. Some doctors do not have an RO, or a Suitable Person, and still organise their own annual appraisal that meets the GMC criteria for a medical appraisal for revalidation.
If you work in a designated body with an organisational appraisal policy, it is your responsibility to understand what that means for you and how you should be accessing your annual appraisal. Your RO has a statutory responsibility for ensuring that the appraisal process is fit for purpose but you must play your part in engaging fully with the process.
We recommend that you are proactive in ensuring that you have an annual appraisal that is meaningful and meets your personal and professional development needs in the context in which you work. If your appraisal becomes disproportionately burdensome, we recommend that you speak to your appraiser and RO. They can support you and make recommendations.
If you think that you should be offered an appraisal and you are not, we recommend that you are proactive about seeking advice from your designated body and ensuring that you are included in the appraisal
process. Administrative errors do happen and you are best placed to highlight such omissions.

Will The Medical Appraiser Decide About My GMC Revalidation Recommendation?
This video clears the commonly held misconception that appraisers decide the revalidation recommendation for doctors.

key insight:

Appraiser's Role: The primary role of the appraiser is to facilitate the doctor's reflection, provide support, stimulate development, and help present an appropriate portfolio of supporting information for the Responsible Officer (RO) to consider.
Facilitating Documentation: Appraisers play a crucial role in producing a comprehensive summary of the evidence supplied by the doctor, representing them to the RO. This involves ensuring that the documentation complies with the requirements for revalidation.
RO's Statutory Responsibility: The RO holds the statutory responsibility for making the revalidation recommendation to the General Medical Council (GMC). The RO's decision is based on factors such as the doctor's engagement in annual appraisal, the quality of the supporting information portfolio, and any outstanding concerns within the scope of work.
GMC Revalidation Decision: Ultimately, the GMC makes the revalidation decision, determining whether to continue the doctor's license to practice.
Appraiser as a Resource: While the appraiser does not make the revalidation decision, they are a valuable resource in helping doctors improve the quality of documentation, especially in areas such as the quality of reflection and the relevance of supporting information across the entire scope of work.
Importance of Engagement: The video highlights that insufficient engagement is often related to the quality of reflection and the relevance of supporting information across the entire scope of work.
Professional Development Planning: Appraisers can support doctors in planning their professional development in a way that enhances the quality of their professional work.

Who Decides On The Medical Appraisal Venue?
The appraisal venue should be mutually agreed between the appraisee and the appraiser and you should not feel pressured into meeting at a venue that does not suit you.



key insights:

Importance of Appraisal Environment: The video emphasizes that the most valuable appraisals occur in an environment that is private, confidential, and conducive to safe reflection and discussion. The choice of venue plays a significant role in the effectiveness of the appraisal process.

Mutual Agreement on Venue: The decision on the appraisal venue should be mutually agreed upon by both the appraisee (doctor being appraised) and the appraiser. There should be no pressure on the appraisee to meet in a venue that does not suit them.

Flexibility in Venue Choice: If the appraisee doesn't have a suitable professional venue or prefers to meet away from their workplace, it may be appropriate for them to travel to the appraiser or choose an alternate professional venue.

Designated Body's Policies: Some designated bodies may have specific arrangements outlined in their medical appraisal policy regarding venue choices. Appraisees should be aware of and adhere to any local requirements set by their designated bodies.

Requirements of a Professional Venue: Regardless of the venue chosen, it should meet certain criteria, including being private, free from interruptions, and equipped with necessary facilities like internet access.

Exceptional Circumstances: In exceptional circumstances, it might be appropriate to hold an appraisal meeting in an unusual venue, such as a home office. However, this decision should be agreed upon in writing with the appraisal leader before the meeting, and the agreement should be documented.

How To Collect Colleague Feedback For A Medical Appraisal?
In our profession, feedback is a vital tool for improvement. It helps us understand our strengths, areas for improvement and how our actions affect patients and colleagues. In the United Kingdom, collecting colleague and patient feedback is an essential part of a medical appraisal. Let's delve into how to go about it.
Firstly, you need to identify who will provide feedback. For colleague feedback, select a broad range of individuals who work with you in a professional capacity. This could include other doctors, nurses, administrative staff, and allied health professionals. For patient feedback, choose a representative sample from your patient population.
Next, we need to consider the method of collection. The General Medical Council (GMC) recommends using validated questionnaires for this purpose. These are designed to provide objective, quantifiable data. You can use the GMC patient and colleague questionnaires, or other validated tools that meet the GMC's requirements.
Once you've selected your colleagues and patients, you need to distribute the questionnaires. This can be done in person, via email, or through a third-party service. It's important to ensure that the process is anonymous and confidential to encourage honest feedback.
After the questionnaires have been completed and returned, you need to analyse the feedback. Look for common themes and areas for improvement. This analysis will form a key part of your appraisal discussion.
Lastly, it's important to act on the feedback received. Create a development plan that addresses any areas for improvement identified. This is not just a requirement for revalidation, but also a way to improve your practice and patient care.
To sum up, collecting feedback is a crucial part of the medical appraisal process. It allows us to reflect on our practice, identify areas for improvement, and improve patient care. Remember, feedback is a tool for growth, not a measure of failure.

Supporting Information For A Medical Appraisal
The GMC requires doctors to provide appropriate supporting information across the whole of their scope of practice that requires a licence to practise, not just clinical roles.
You must declare all parts of your scope of practice and, for each of them where appropriate, provide all
six types of supporting information over the revalidation cycle:
l CPD
l QIA
l significant events, if there are any
l patient feedback
l colleague feedback
l complaints and compliments, if there are any
We recommend that you keep the documentation of your supporting information reasonable and proportionate while ensuring that you have demonstrated that you are up-to-date and fit to practise in every scope of practice. Your appraiser will help you determine whether there are any gaps in your portfolio of supporting information and support you in working out how best to fill those gaps. Your responsible officer (RO) will tell you if your portfolio demonstrates sufficient engagement in reflective practice and provides the supporting information required by the GMC.
If you have any queries that your appraiser cannot resolve, we recommend that you seek early confirmation from your RO that what you are planning is going to be acceptable.
Content: Mythbusters@RCGP


Key insights:

Scope of Practice: The GMC (General Medical Council) requires doctors to provide appropriate supporting information across the entire scope of their practice that requires a license, not just clinical roles. This encompasses all aspects of a doctor's professional responsibilities.

Six Types of Supporting Information: For each part of the scope of practice, doctors need to provide all six types of supporting information over the revalidation cycle. These include CPD (Continuous Professional Development), quality improvement activities, significant events, patient feedback, colleague feedback, and information about any complaints and compliments.

Documentation Management: It is recommended to keep the documentation of supporting information reasonable and proportionate while ensuring that it demonstrates being up-to-date and fit to practice in every aspect of the scope of practice.

how to complete appraisal portfolio For your appraisal, you'll need to gather six types of supporting information required by the GMC: CPD, QIA, SE, feedback from patients or colleagues, and review of compliments/complaints.   If you need pre-appraisal coaching, we can do this for you as well.  Let us know.

I Need To Undertake A 1000 Hrs Of Work For GMC Revalidation!! Help Me!
Revalidation assesses your fitness to practise as a doctor. There are no GMC requirements that relate to the number of sessions you need to work in any role. You need to be confident that you can demonstrate that you practise safely in every role you undertake, no matter how little of that work you do.


Key insights:

Assessment of Fitness to Practice:
Revalidation assesses a doctor's fitness to practice, and there are no specific General Medical Council (GMC) requirements regarding the number of sessions or hours a doctor needs to undertake in any role.

Confidence in Safe Practice:
The emphasis is on doctors being confident in demonstrating safe practice in every role they undertake, regardless of the amount of time spent in that role or part of their scope of practice.

Reflective Practice Expectations:
Doctors are expected to reflect on how they keep themselves up-to-date, review their practice, and ensure that their practice remains safe for patients.

Feedback Collection:
The GMC expects doctors to seek out and respond to feedback from colleagues and patients, fostering a continuous improvement approach.

Significant Breaks from Practice:
There may be times when doctors experience significant breaks from practice, such as maternity or parental leave, sickness, or sabbaticals. Designated bodies have mechanisms to agree on postponing appraisals or approving missed appraisals for such situations.

Differentiation from Low Clinical Work Volumes:
Approved breaks in practice are distinguished from situations where doctors have low volumes of clinical work on an ongoing basis.

Option of Deferral:
If necessary, the Responsible Officer (RO) has the option to defer revalidation, providing more time for doctors to collect the required supporting information.
Dr.  Kazi mentioned about filling a appraisal form and I had queries about that Sure - try me and if you need pre-appraisal coaching, we can sort this out for you as well

Do I Need To Provide Supporting Information Only About My Clinical Role For Medical Appraisal?
The GMC requires doctors to provide appropriate supporting information across the whole of their scope of practice that requires a licence to practise, not just clinical roles. 
From: https://www.rcgp.org.uk/-/media/Files/GP-training-and-exams/Mythbusters/RCGP-mythbusters-may-2019.ashx?la=en

Key insights:

Scope of Practice: The General Medical Council (GMC) requires doctors to provide appropriate supporting information across the entire scope of their practice that requires a license to practice. This extends beyond clinical roles to encompass all aspects of their professional responsibilities.

Declaration of Scope: Doctors must declare all parts of their scope of practice, and for each, provide the six types of supporting information over the revalidation cycle:

Continuing Professional Development (CPD)
Quality Improvement Activity (QIA)
Significant Events
Patient Feedback
Colleague Feedback
Complaints and Compliments
Documentation Guidelines: The Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) recommends keeping the documentation of supporting information reasonable and proportionate while ensuring that it demonstrates being up to date and fit to practice across all scopes.

Appraiser Support: The appraiser will assist in determining whether there are any gaps in the portfolio of supporting information across the entire scope of practice and provide support in addressing those gaps.

Role of Responsible Officer (RO): The Responsible Officer (RO) will assess whether the portfolio demonstrates sufficient engagement in reflective practice and includes the supporting information required by the GMC.

Confirmation from RO: If there are queries that the appraiser cannot resolve, seeking early confirmation from the Responsible Officer is recommended to ensure that the planned approach is acceptable.

Engagement in Reflective Practice: The portfolio should demonstrate the doctor's engagement in reflective practice, and the supporting information provided should meet the standards set by the GMC.
